thread.title: UL to face La. Tech in intriguing matchup
thread.title_full: UL to face La. Tech in intriguing matchup

title: UL to face La. Tech in intriguing matchup
text:
UL to face La. Tech in intriguing matchup Bobby Ardoin 11:51 a.m. CDT October 1, 2015 Cajuns running back Elijah McGuire runs against Akron at Cajun Field. (Photo: Mike Curley/Special to the Daily World) 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
How many intriguing contemporary layers can be added to the already historic UL-Louisiana Tech football rivalry? 
Try matching two of the most prolific active running backs in the NCAA. 
Or what about the Cajuns’ attempt to reverse a seven-game Tech winning streak that dates back to 1997? 
How about Tech quarterback Jeff Driskel, who two years ago guided Florida to a last-minute victory over the Cajuns? 
Those are just several of the underlying themes available Saturday beginning at 6 p.m. at Joe Aillet Stadium in Ruston when the Cajuns (1-2) and Tech (2-2) meet for the 87th time since 1910. 
Lately the Bulldogs have dominated the outcomes between the teams, including last year’s 48-20 victory at Cajun Field. 
Two of the nation’s top running backs in Tech’s Kenneth Dixon and Elijah McGuire of UL meet for the second straight year. 
The pair have combined for over 8,000 career all-purpose yards. Dixon ranks first among current NCAA players (4,593), while McGuire has 3,553. 
This season Dixon has run for 524. McGuire has 331. 
In last year’s win, Dixon ran for a 98-yard touchdown. 
Driskel transferred to Tech two years ago and this season he has already thrown for 1,171 yards. 
The rivalry apparently has not been understated in either Ruston or Lafayette this week. 
UL head football coach Mark Hudspeth said he has been especially mindful of Saturday’s game. Hudspeth said after last year’s loss his players have been more than cognizant of the importance of the contest. 
“They heard from me about this game after we lost to (Tech) last year. Then they heard about it all spring and summer. Our players remember how they felt after (last year’s game) was over. 
“Tech came in here last year with a chip on their shoulder and we will go up there this weekend with one on our shoulders,” Hudspeth said this week. 
Tech head football coach Skip Holtz said the atmosphere surrounding the UL game is different. 
“This is a game that everyone looks forward to from a fan base standpoint, from a coach’s standpoint and from a player’s standpoint,” Holtz said during his weekly press conference. 
“It builds an immediate rivalry geographically. I know everyone wants bragging rights and it creates a lot of excitement and energy,” he said. 
Hudspeth said much of made of a perceived recruiting advantage for the winning team, but he said that’s not always the case. 
“This is the type of game that is more for the fans and the bragging rights. Recruiting is year to year. This is a type of game that brings out our fans, former players and pride for your university. Your players want to play awafully hard,” Hudspeth said. 
While Driskel is set to play quarterback, the Cajuns are still unsettled at the position. 
Hduspeth said he is re-examining the Cajuns’ quarterback situation and will choose between three-game starter Brooks Haack and Jalen Nixon. 
Holtz said he is worried about the UL rushing game, which is ranked No. 19 in the FBS. 
Especially effective is McGuire, said Holtz. 
“I really like Elijah McGuire. I think he is pretty electric with the ball under his arm,” said Holtz. 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://www.dailyworld.com/story/sports/college/ul/2015/10/01/ul-face-la-tech-intriguing-matchup/73147912/ TOP VIDEOS
